item.title: About Us
item.dc:creator: dsnel0lx
item.content:encoded:
The SGA Constitution

The SGA Constitution is the governing document of the organization. To read the document click here. Currently the student body has the opportunity to vote on suggestions to approve the changes to the SGA Constitution. Some of the changes are minor while others are larger in nature. Please read the proposed changes below and if you have questions and their explanations below and  feel free to contact us at sga@mail.umw.edu.

Article VI. Section 6

Add the bolded section under the position of President:

The President shall appoint the SGA Secretary, Treasurer, Executive Coordinator, Communications Director, Director of Community Outreach and the Technology Coordinator of the Executive Cabinet with the approval of the Student Senate.

Last year, the Executive Cabinet was expanded to work with the community more and improve communications with students. These changes reflect that expansion. Remove the bolded section under the Position of Secretary:

The Secretary is responsible for the upkeep of all SGA Bulletin Boards. The Secretary is responsible for all publicity for the SGA. The Secretary shall work with the Senate for publicity reasons whenever necessary.

This is a clerical change. These responsibilities have been given to the Communications Director. Add the bolded section under the position of Technology Coordinator:

The Technology Coordinator is also responsible for all of the Executive Cabinet’s social media and online presence. Rename the Position Director of Communications to Communications Director.

Because the Communications Director is fairly new, boundaries have to be set to ensure each positions job is clear. The Technology Director will be solely responsible for all digital media while the Communications Director will work on all published “print” media. Rewrite the following sentence under Communications Director:

The Communications Director will have the power and responsibility to create and Chair a Communications Committee as directed by the SGA President. The Communications Director is responsible for the up keep of all SGA Publicity that is not digital. The Communications Director shall work with the Senate for publicity reasons whenever necessary.

Rename the Position of the Involvement and Outreach Coordinator to the Director of Community Outreach.

Remove the bolded statement from the Director of Community Outreach

This position will act as a liaison and inform/update the SGA President on the activities of the local city governance. Additionally this position is responsible for volunteer participation, including recruitment, supervision and scheduling that involve the local community and Fredericksburg Area.

This is the LAC Chairs job. This change is clerical in nature. Add the bolded portion to the position description of Director of Community Outreach:

This position is responsible for volunteer participation, including recruitment, supervision and scheduling that involve the local community and Fredericksburg Area.

This will allow the Director of Community Outreach to oversee all SGA Community Outreach Projects. Add the bolded portion to the position description of the Director of Community Outreach

The director will work closely with the Communications Director, Executive Coordinator, the Commuter Student Association President and Legislative Action Committee Chair in terms of promotion and public relations development through community education, involvement and support.  

This will allow the Director of Community Outreach to oversee all SGA Community Outreach Projects.

Article VI, Section 9

Add the bolded Section to the removal clause:

In case of the removal or resignation of the Judicial Review Board President, Honor Council President, Legislative Action Committee Chairperson, Academic Affairs Council Chairperson, Association of Residence Hals President, Commuting Student Association President or Inter-Club Association President from office, the power and duties should temporarily to the respective Vice-President or Vice-Chairperson.

This gives the ICA President instructions incase of the removal or resignation of their President. It also makes accommodations for defines removal and resignation.   Add the bolded Section to Section 13 (to take effect in 2014):

Elected Executive Cabinet members may not hold positions within Senate or Senate Board, with the Exception of the SGA Vice-President. No member of the Executive Cabinet may serve as a member of the Finance Committee (elected or appointed). 

The Finance Committee has been separate from the SGA however, their members are allowed to serve on the committee. By not allowing any member of the Executive Cabinet to serve on the Committee, more students will be granted leadership opportunities while keeping Finance Committee completely separate from SGA making it more fair for students. 

Article VII, Section 2

Remove the bolded section from Section 2

The Executive Cabinet shall approve or veto any legislation enacted by the Senate within two weeks,lest the legislation is appropriated to the correct body or the legislation is automatically vetoed.

If the Executive Cabinet does not vote in legislation within two weeks it is automatically vetoed, allowing the Senate to override that veto with a 2/3 majority. This is the same as it works in the United States Government.

Article VII, Section 8

Add the following bolded section to Section 8:

The Senate Vice-President must be a senator, with at least two consecutive semester of experience as a senator (including the semester of elections), and shall be elected by his/her fellow senators during the third meeting of the Senate in the Fall Semester and hold no other office within the senate.

This change allows for the Senate Vice President’s qualification to align with the SGA Vice Presidents qualifications.

item.title: Get Involved
item.dc:creator: dsnel0lx
item.content:encoded:
You are here: Home / Student Clubs and Organizations / List of Student Clubs

List of Student Clubs

  Clubs which are not officially recognized by the Inter-Club Association (ICA) are in italics. You can also find information about registered clubs on OrgSync. Club Sports are listed at Campus Recreation. Please contact the Office of Student Activities and Engagement at sae@umw.edu or 540- 654-1061 if you have any questions.  Faculty Advisors’ UMW phone extensions are in parenthesis (prefix with 1-540-654 if dialing from outside of the University).
Club Name
Description
Contact Information
African Student Union OrgSync The primary goal of the African Student Union is to spread awareness about the different African cultures. We strive to overcome stereotypes and create unity within our community. Our club also dedicates its time to support a variety of African charities. Student Contact: Ayida Getachew Faculty Advisor: Taiwo Ande
Aikido at UMW The purpose of Aikido is to teach students the act of Aikido, a martial art developed in Japan. Student Contact: Daniel Ryer Faculty Advisor: Larry Penwell(x1561)
Alpha Mu Sigma (AMS)  OrgSync Alpha Mu Sigma is a local, social fraternity that strives to unite the Mary Washington community with a lifelong bond via community service and bonding activities. Student Contact: Jill Burke Faculty Advisor: Joe Mollo(x1061)
Alter Egos Step Team OrgSync Stepping is a type of dance that uses clapping and stomping that make unique beats to music. Student Contact: Jeneka Holmes Faculty Advisor: Marion Sanford(x1044)
Alternative Spring Break Donate your spring break to a good cause with COAR! Student Contact: Shayda Rezazad Faculty Advisor: Christian Eggenberger
American Marketing Association We exist to enhance interested students’ knowledge about the marketing industry and careers. Student Contact: Brooke Comfort Raven Carroll Faculty Advisor: Carol Ann Creque
Arabic Language Club OrgSync To promote the study of Arabic language and raise awareness of Arab customs and culture in the campus community. Student Contact: Marjahn Goodman Faculty Advisor: Nabil Al-Takriti(x1481)
Asian Student Association (ASA) OrgSync The Asian Student Association seeks to promote the appreciation and understanding of Asia through social, educational and cultural activities. ASA is a unified student body that does not consist of members solely of Asian descent. Student Contact: Gina Noh Faculty Advisor:  Kevin Handley
Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) OrgSync The chapter is organized and will be operated exclusively for educational and scientific purposes to promote the increasing of knowledge of and greater interest in the science, design, development, construction, languages, management, and applications of modern computing, and as a means of communication between persons having an interest in computing. Student Contact:  Jessica White Faculty Advisor:  Stephen Davies
Association of Residence Halls (ARH) OrgSync ARH represents residential students on SGA and provides guidance to the residence hall councils. Student Contact:  Alyssa Lieurance  Faculty Advisor:
Aubade OrgSync Aubade is the annual literary arts magazine. They seek to showcase the artistic and literary talents of UMW students. Student Contact: Jenna Randall  Faculty Advisor: Colin Rafferty
Baby Steps OrgSync Baby Steps aims to develop resources at UMW for parenting students and staff, and to foster an environment that supports such students and their families. Student Contact:  Carly Boucher Faculty Advisor:  Stephen Davies(x1317)
Baptist Collegiate Ministries College is a time of transformation. It’s a time to question. To learn. To grow. The BCM is a place where it’s safe to ask questions and to wrestle with what is good, true, and beautiful. It’s a place where all of the disparate parts of life are brought together and made whole. Will you join us? The campus minister can be contacted at Carey.Sims@vbmb.org Student Contact:  Rachel Eiker  Faculty Advisor:  Stephen Davies
Baseball OrgSync Club sport for men seeking to play baseball competitively. Student Contact: Mark Christiansen Faculty Advisor: Mark Mermelstein
Basketball (Men’s) Men’s Club Basketball is a group designed to deliver a competitive basketball atmosphere within the confines of the average college student. Student Contact:  Alex Ritler  Faculty Advisor:  Melissa Yakabowki
Basketball (Women’s) OrgSync The club is for people who want a fun and competitive environment. We fundraise and volunteer in the Fredericksburg community. Student Contact:  Alex Miller Faculty Advisor: Mark Mermelstein
Battlefield Yearbook OrgSync The Battlefield provides the UMW students with a yearbook capturing the academic school year’s memories. Student Contact: Karmel James Faculty Advisor: Joe Mollo
BellA’capella OrgSync BellACapella is an all girls A’capella singing group that has been around for over 10 years. We bring a wide array of songs from all genres to our campus. Student Contact:  Katherine Preseren Faculty Advisor: Deborah O’Dell
Best Buddies OrgSync College students are matched in one-to-one friendships with people in the community with intellectual and developmental disabilities and take part in group and individual activities. Student Contact:  Casey Dodrill  Faculty Advisor:  Virgina Mackintosh
Biology Club OrgSync Biology Club is meant to connect those who are biology majors or interested in biology to resources in the department and school to further their interest. It helps connect people who are majors to scientific opportunities inside and outside the university. Student Contact: Sarah McCue Faculty Advisor:  Joella Killian(x1418)
Black Student Association (BSA) OrgSync The purpose of our club is to try and bring together students of black descent and all races together and have a good time Student Contact: Romadon Stovall  Faculty Advisor:  Marion Sanford(x1044)
Blue Tide Lacrosse (Men’s) OrgSync We are the men’s club lacrosse team, Blue Tide. Our purpose is to provide students with the opportunity to continue playing at a competitive level and advance their skills. All skill levels are welcomed and we are open to teaching the sport rules and regulations to players who are new to lacrosse. Student Contact: Joseph Krzywicki  Faculty Advisor:  Dave Pierandi(x1662)
Boxing OrgSync UMW Boxing is for students to learn the basics and fundamentals of boxing, practice form and technique, and spar with one another. Student Contact: Alex Decina Faculty Advisor:  Larry Penwell
Breakers Analyzing and practicing the art of break dancing, alongside other aspects of hip-hop. Student Contact: Justin Yi Faculty Advisor: Beverly Mendez
Brothers of a New Direction (BOND) A club that promotes brotherhood through unity and togetherness; in the end we all come together as one. Student Contact: Romadon Stovall Faculty Advisor:  Marion Sanford
The Bullet OrgSync The Bullet is the University of Mary Washington’s student-run newspaper. It provides the UMW community with campus, local, national and world news, as well as editorials, sports and entertainment. Student Contact: Thomas Bowman Faculty Advisor: Michael McCarthy
Class Council  OrgSync Class Council coordinates and maintains all traditional class-wide events. Our non-profit organization functions as a separate entity from Student Government Association. The intention of Class Council is to provide inexpensive social activities for the student body. Student Contact: Jennifer Crystle Faculty Advisor:  Megan Higginbotham
Campus Christian Community (CCC) OrgSync Welcoming all people, the CCC ministers with students, faculty and staff at the University of Mary Washington through worship, fellowship and service, and provides a forum to explore questions of faith and life. Student Contact:  Sarah Davis Elizabeth Storey Facultuy Advisor: Joe Mollo
Campus Scouts OrgSync Campus Scouts is group that volunteers with local scouting groups in the Fredericksburg area by planning educational events, helping with cookie sales, and mentoring scouts of all ages. Student Contact: Kate Gibson Faculty Advisor: Joni Wilson(x2088)
Canterbury Club Canterbury is a campus ministry geared towards students from the Episcopal/Anglican and Lutheran traditions, although we welcome students of other Christian backgrounds. We strive to be an open, inclusive and questioning community of faith for students who are seeking to follow Christ while at college. Student Contact:  Taylor Poindexter Facultuy Advisor: Deborah O’Dell(x1417)
Catholic Campus Ministries OrgSync Catholic Campus Ministry is organized by the Catholic students of the University of Mary Washington, in conjunction with the Catholic Diocese of Arlington. The CCM’s mission is to provide a sound Roman Catholic spiritual center for the students, staff, and faculty at UMW. Our goal is to apply the Gospel of Our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ in all of our activities. Student Contact: Tracy Frelk Faculty Advisor: Elizabeth Larus(x1497)
Cheap Seats Cinema OrgSync Cheap Seats strives to bring quality film entertainment to the UMW community with block buster movies on campus for a low fee of $1. Movies are shown almost every weekend in Monroe 116. Student Contact:  Angela Damergis Faculty Advisor:  Joe Mollo
Cheerleading OrgSync The goal of the UMW Cheerleading Club is to promote school spirit by cheering for men’s and women’s varsity basketball. We hold practice three times each week during which we work to improve our cheerleading skills in a fun, supportive, friendly but also challenging environment. All skill levels are welcome to join us in supporting the “Eagle Nation” Student Contact: Kimberly Ellis Faculty Advisor: Mark Mermelstein
Children of Time OrgSync The purpose of COT is to look at the science fiction of the modern word: how it depicts possible futures, the metaphors for modern issues that we deal every day, and the issues we have dealt with in the past. Student Contact: Robert Hill  Faculty Advisor: Joseph Romero(x1340)
Circle K International OrgSync Circle K is the college level of Key Club. We are a tight-knit, enthusiastic community service club focused on our three tenants of leadership, fellowship and service. Student Contact: Kelly Griffith Faculty Advisor:  Marisa Martinez-Mira
Civil War Reenactors Club We are a club that participates in re-enacting histories and battles. We interpret history to the public through re-enacting and we go to many battlefields and historical sites. Student Contact: Sean Redmiles Faculty Advisor: Krystyn Moon
Classics Club OrgSync Classics Club meets to discuss and enjoy classical languages and history. We are interested in anything to do with Ancient Classical Civilizations such as Greece and Rome. Student Contact: Ana Tkabladze Faculty Advisor: Joseph Romero
College Republicans The College Republicans support local Republican candidates for office and meet to discuss current events. Student Contact: Elizabeth Brennan Faculty Advisor: Leigh Frackelton
Commuter Student Association OrgSync The Commuter Student Association (CSA) is an official UMW organization dedicated to serving the needs of the commuter student population. Student Contact: Ally Blanck Faculty Advisor: Chris Porter
Dance Team The UMW Dance Team promotes school spirit by perfomring at school functions, pep rallies, home basketball games, and Homecoming. Student Contact: Anne Grasselli Gaelyn Quirey Faculty Advisor: Chad Murphey(x1061)
Dodgeball Club The Dodgeball Club’s primary function is to organize and fund dodgeball games open to everyone two to three times a week outside of Bushnell in the basketball cage. In addition, we will travel to compete in dodgeball tournaments, and host tournaments with proceeds going to charity. Student Contact: Ian Potere Faculty Advisor: Michael Pearson 
Eagle Bhangra Eagle Bhangra contributes meaningfully to the diversity experience at UMW. This organization is a performance team that appeals to students of all cultures that are interested in the dance, dress, and dynamic present of Bhangra’s South Asian and Central Asian roots. Student Contact: Upma Kapoor Faculty Advisor: Smita Jain Oxford (x1454)
Eagle Nation Eagle Nation is a spirit committee devoted to showing the student support of various activities ranging from athletic events to Mary Washington fundraisers. Student Contact: David Carpenter Katie Sue Van Valkenburg Faculty Advisor: Kim Tomlin(x1061)
Ecology Club OrgSync Our meetings are every Thursday at 8:00 pm in Lee Hall Room 412. Once a month we will be attending the local Sierra Club meetings instead of having general meetings. Student Contact: Samantha Corron Faculty Advisor: Melanie Szulczeuski(x2345)
Enigma Colorguard OrgSync We combine dance with spinning flags, rifles and sabres, and put it to music to tell a story. Student Contact: Nicole Erickson Faculty Advisor: Beverly Mendez(x1243)
Economics Club The UMW Economics Club is a club open to all UMW students which holds enjoyable economics-related events. Student Contact: Marissa Yoder Faculty Advisor: Shawn Humphrey(x1487)
Encore OrgSync We are a show choir performance club. Our goal is to promote UMW spirit through a mutual love of music and dance. Student Contact: Catherine Gauthier Faculty Advisor: Beverly Mendez(x1317)
Encounter OrgSync Encounter exists to help students come in contact with biblical truth and biblical community with a real life application. It is working in association with Spotswood Baptist Church. Student Contact: Stephanie Battleson Faculty Advisor: Stephen Davies(x1317)
ELC Club OrgSync Our purpose as a club is to create a connection within the ELC community, through establishing bonds between the students and faculty, via a monthly Q and A series, trips to book readings downtown and within the state, visits to performances in DC/on campus, opportunities to network with alumni, in hopes of establishing a solid community of language lovers. Student Contact: Tonto Duncan Faculty Advisor:
Feminists United On Campus OrgSync This club is about equality, the exchange of information, work in the community, and the celebration of feminism! Student Contact: Annie Truslow Faculty Advisor: Tracy Citeroni Chris Kilmartin
Mary Washington Fencing Club OrgSync MW Fencing teaches students how to compete in the Olympic sport of fencing in a friendly environment The club welcomes all level of experience and will also provide equipment. En garde! Student Contact: Jenna Stockton Faculty Advisor: Zach Whalen
Field Hockey OrgSync Club Field Hockey is an organization that provides the opportunity for any student to have a fun time playing field hockey and competing with other universities. Student Contact: Ashley Bruce Faculty Advisor: Kim Tomlin
Finance Committee Finance Committee allocates funds to ICA Clubs on campus. Student Contact: Monique Dela Cruz Faculty Advisor: Joe Mollo
Future Business Leaders of America (FBLA) OrgSync FBLA is an opportunity for students to get more involved with the business major. We help clubs market on campus, host leadership activities, and volunteer. Student Contact: Kathleen Kutnak Faculty Advisor: Dan Hubbard(x1460)
The Gathering OrgSync An on-campus, non-denominational Bible study led by an awesome local pastor. Each semester we do an in-depth study of one book of the Bible, seeking to gain a deeper understanding of God’s word and how we can apply it to our lives. Student Contact: Gemma Cohen Faculty Advisor: Stephen Davies(x1317)
Geography Club Spreading the love and knowledge of all things Geography! Student Contact: David Chambers Faculty Advisor: Jackie Gallagher(x1493)
German Club OrgSync UMW German Club’s purpose is to promote the German language and culture in a fun and educational way. Student Contact: Kelsey Wilson Faculty Advisor: Marcel Rotter(x1996)
Giant Productions OrgSync Giant Productions is in charge of bringing entertainment to UMW – comedians, musicians, etc. Giant books events and so students can have a great time. From the meetings Giant decides what the campus most wants to see and tries to make it happen. Giant brings as much entertainment as possible while making it as accessible as possible. Student Contact: Lonnie Southall Faculty Advisor: Joe Mollo
Historic Preservation Club OrgSync The purpose of the Historic Preservation Club is to promote preservation to our majors, the campus community, and downtown Fredericksburg. We strive to educate club members and others on up to date preservation issues through many different venues Student Contact: Susanna Parmelee Faculty Advisor:  Gary Stanton(x1313)
Honor Council OrgSync Educating and upholding honor throughout the campus and beyond. Student Contact: Zandi Larmour Faculty Advisor:  Doug Searcy(x1062)
Humans vs. Zombies Club OrgSync The purpose of Humans vs. Zombies is to engage in team work, to create deep bonds between players, to foster communication between teammates and other players, and to create strategies based on missions and obstacles. Humans vs. Zombies is a game of moderated tag played at schools across the world. Human players must remain vigilant and defend themselves with socks and Nerf guns to avoid being tagged by a growing zombie horde. Student Contact: Eileen Coxe Faculty Advisor:  Eric Bonds(x1436)
Inter-Club Association We advice and oversee all ICA-approved clubs. Student Contact: Faculty Advisor: Joe Mollo(x1061)
InterVarsity Christian Fellowship OrgSync IV is an inter-denominational Christian fellowship, pursuing Christ’s gift of love and salvation on the UMW campus. We are a group passionately devoted to Jesus, and sharing him with the world. Student Contact: Bethany Apelquist Faculty Advisor: Stephen Stageberg(x1486)
Invisible Children OrgSync Invisible Children raises awareness about Africa’s longest running civil war, as well as raising funds for relief projects on the ground. Student Contact: Stephanie Preston Faculty Advisor: Elizabeth Larus (x1497)
Islamic Student Association (ISA) OrgSync The purpose of ISA shall be to raise cultural awareness of Islam and Islamic culture, to widen and increase the knowledge of young people in Islam, to be a visible presence on the UMW campus, and to serve those in need in our community. Student Contact: Aqsa Zafar Faculty Advisor:  Medhi Aminrazavi(x1341)
Japanese Animated and Dramatic Entertainment (J.A.D.E.) OrgSync The purpose of J.A.D.E. is to showcase the cultural variety of Japanese animated entertainment, as well as to provide a forum where Japanese history, language, art, myths, games, and music can be discussed and enjoyed. Student Contact: Andrew Beichler Faculty Advisor:  Kevin McClusky(x1979)
Jewish Student Association / Hillel (JSA) OrgSync Our mission is to promote Jewish life on Mary Washington’s campus through both cultural and religious activities. Further, we aim to add to the overall diversity of Mary Washington’s student body by promotion tolerance, communication, and education. Student Contact:  Hallie Feingold Zach Feinstein  Faculty Advisor:  David Rettinger(x1364)
Judicial Review Board (JRB) The Judicial Review Boardhandles judicial matters on campus dealing with minor student policy violations. Student Contact: Elizabeth Brennan Faculty Advisor: Ray Tuttle (x1527)
Lacrosse Club (Women’s) Cool girls. Cool lacrosse. Cool. Student Contact: Kandra Selby Faculty Advisor:  Mary Beth Mathews (x1354)
Latin Dance Club OrgSync The Latin Dance Club teaches interested students how to dance common Latino dances such as salsa, merengue, and bachata. Student Contact: Elizabeth Matute Faculty Advisor:  Marisa Martinez Mira (x1986)
Latino Student Assocation (LSA) OrgSync To expose and enhance Latino-American culture at UMW through celebration, volunteerism and support for students and residents alike from every background, ethnicity and age. Student Contact: Mayra Flores-Valderde Faculty Advisor: Maria Laura Bocaz
Master Plan Awareness Club (Impact) – Our goal is to inform students about the changes on campus related to the master plan for the purposes of inviting discussion, celebrating campus history and inspiring future alumni to bond with the landscape. Student Contact: Gwendolyn Corkill Faculty Advisor: Gregg Stull(x1980)
Mathematical Association of America, UMW Student Chapter OrgSync The MAA student group works closely with faculty, mathematics majors, and any mathematically-inclined students in hosting activities advancing interest in all aspects of mathematics. The student group of the MAA is affiliated with the national office of the Mathematical Association of America, a professional organization which includes university faculty and students of all levels. Student Contact: Candice Bensoff Faculty Advisor: Randall Helmstutler(x1329)
MedLife OrgSync Our mission is to help families achieve greater freedom from the constraints of poverty, empowering them to live healthier lives. Our patients did not choose to be poor, but they have chosen to strive toward a better life; MEDLIFE stands beside them in this pursuit. Student Contact: Marco Montero Faculty Advisor:
Mock Trial Team UMW’s Mock Trial team competes in college mock trial competitions organized by the American Mock Trial Association. Each year, AMTA releases a criminal or civil case. UMW’s Mock Trial Team prepares a defense case, a prosecution case, and witnesses for each side. At each competition UMW’s prosecution competes against the defense team of other schools and vice versa. In the 2011-2012 competition year UMW’s Mock Trial team ranked high enough at the Regional Tournament to go on to the first round of the Championships. Student Contact: Aissata Traore Faculty Advisor: Ghislaine Storr Burks
Model United Nations OrgSync Model UN is an organization of students with an interest in politics, history, diplomacy, and international issues. We attend several college conferences annually to debate real United Nations concerns, as well as win awards. We practice debate, writing and research skills in a fun, dynamic setting. Student Contact: Courtney Cherico Faculty Advisor: Jason Davidson
National Society of Collegiate Scholars OrgSync NSCS is a student honor society dedicated to leadership and community service. NSCS holds many charity events and hosts spirit weeks. It is an active on-campus presence to members and non-members alike. Student Contact: Hanna Lehnen Faculty Advisor: Ray Tuttle(x1660)
No Labels at UMW OrgSync No Labels is a national bipartisan organization committed to fighting against the growing divide in our government between Republicans and Democrats. Our congressional and presidential reforms are designed to encourage our leaders to compromise and stop the ongoing issues within the legislature. Student Contact: Camille Turner Faculty Advisor: Stephen Farnsworth(x11404)
New Life College Connection College Connection is a ministry of New Life in Christ Church. We are a Christian community for the “convinced” and the “unconvinced.” College Connection is a place where students can ask hard questions about Christianity and grow in their understanding of Christian life. Student Contact: Caroline Bender Faculty Advisor: Christopher Garcia (x1456)
Object Manipulation Group (OMG) OrgSync The purpose of OMG is to promote and advance the art of juggling, hooping, and other forms of object manipulation. Student Contact: Anna Penniman Faculty Advisor: Kenneth Machande
The One Note Stand OrgSync One Note Stand is a co-ed A Cappella group that provides the UMW campus and surrounding community with student arranged music covering genres from pop to oldies, hip hop, jazz, indie, choral, original music, and more. Student Contact: Regina Weiss Faculty Advisor: Paul Griggs
Operation Smile Operation Smile is a non-profit, international organization with the goal to provide cleft palette operations on impoverished children. Through weekly fundraising events, UMW’s Operation Smile chapter hopes to raise awareness of the group’s cause, while concurrently making monetary contributions. Student Contact: Brandee Adams Faculty Advisor: K. Nicole Crowder (x1016)
Orpheum Film Club OrgSync Orpheum seeks to both educate and entertain the students of UMW by screening and discussing classic, independent, and foreign films. The aim is to broaden perspectives by exposing students to films that might otherwise be overlooked. Student Contact: Margaret Boyle  Faculty Advisor: Leonard Koos
Outdoor Club OrgSync Outdoors Club is geared towards group outings that are organized by the club officers. Our trips include kayaking, canoeing, rock climbing, hiking, camping and rafting. Student Contact: Caroline Psaltis Faculty Advisor: Jeremy Larochelle (x1368)
Paws OrgSync Paws is an organization that combines an interest group for animal lovers with an opportunity to volunteer at adoptions and shelters. Student Contact: Natalie Might  Faculty Advisor: Dianne Baker
People for the Rights of Individuals of Sexual Minorities(PRISM) OrgSync The purpose of PRISM is to promote the value of diversity and acceptance of students of sexual and gender minorities and allies of the GLBTTQQIAAP community through club meetings and sponsored events on campus. Student Contact: Kristen Lamb Faculty Advisor: Gary Richards
Performing Arts Club OrgSync The Performing Arts Club offers performance, choreography, and leadership opportunities in dance. PAC dancers hold two shows each semester and offer workshops and other performance opportunities. Student Contact: Courtney Lewandrowski Faculty Contact: Beverly Mendez
PERL OrgSync PERL strives to promote, encourage, recruit, and lead women in technology and computer science as well as promote unity within the computer science department. Student Contact: Bethany Akers Faculty Advisor: Stephen Davies
Pre-Medical / Pre-Dental Club OrgSync The goal of UMW’s Pre-Medicine/Pre-Dental Clubis to foster the desire of UMW students to provide service to those in our community while pursuing a career in healthcare. Student Contact: Ryan Green Angela Damergis Faculty Advisor: Stephen G. Gallik(x1419)
Physical Therapy and Occupational Therapy Club Provide information to students interested in becoming physical therapists or occupational therapists. We provide outlines of the recommended classes and schedule admissions directors of various schools to visit UMW. Student Contact: Kelsey Deppe Faculty Advisor:  Deborah O’Dell
Pre-Vet Club The Pre-Vet Club provides those interested in a veterinary career or other animal related careers with application advice, course advise, and volunteer opportunities. Student Contact: Katelynn Monti Faculty Advisor:  Lynn Lewis(x1415)
Renaissance Club OrgSync The Mary Washington Renaissance Club is devoted to the enthusiastic preservation and recreation of historical customs during the Renaissance period. Student Contact: Kathryn Tarr Faculty Advisor: Theresa Kennedy(x1531)
Rotaract Club Rotaract Club is a service club for the Fredericksburg and Stafford community. Subset of the Rotary Club Student Contact: Casey Ragghianti  Faculty Advisor: Debra Schleef
Rugby Club (Men’s) OrgSync We have been around for over 30 years. There are no cuts, so everyone plays. We are a traveling sport that gives opportunity to play competitive rugby and have fun, Student Contact: Matt McAloon Faculty Advisor: Michael Spencer(x1311)
Rugby Club (Women) OrgSync UMW Women’s Rugby was established in 1985. Since then the club has achieved great success. The season for Women’s Rugby includes both fall and spring semesters with games traditionally held on Saturdays; tournaments are sometimes held on Saturdays and Sundays. Practice is held MWF afternoons from 4pm to 6pm at Hanover Recreation Field. Student Contact: Lara Hampson Faculty Advisor: Mark Mermelstein
Scuba Club OrgSync A club for students to come together and share their interest in scuba diving. Student Contact: Lauren Castello Faculty Advisor: Neil Tilbert
Ski and Snowboard OrgSync A ski and snowboard club for all abilities, seeking powder wherever it falls. Student Contact: David Chambers Rob Jarvis Faculty Advisor: Joseph Romero(x0989)
Soccer (Men’s) OrgSync Playing soccer in a less competitive environment, while having fun. Student Contact: Kyle Nero Faculty Advisor: Mark Mermelstein
Soccer (Women’s) OrgSync UMW Women’s Club Soccer competes in two outdoor seasons and one indoor season each year. We train and play matches in both the spring and fall, and compete indoors to keep our skills sharp in the winter. We practice on Monday, Wednesday and Friday afternoons and play games against other schools in our region on the weekends. We are a competitive team and require commitment and dedication, but anyone is welcome to play with us! Our main goals are improving as a team and just having fun, with outings for ice cream and team dinners. If you lovve to play the game and want to play soccer at a higher level, please contact us! Student Contact: Grace Christenson Faculty Advisor: Mark Mermelstein
Society of Pre-Law OrgSync The Society of Pre-Law is a student organization for those interested in the field of law. Our purpose is to network, prepare, and surround ourselves with other students interested in pursuing legal work. Student Contact: Chelsea Chamberlain Faculty Advisor: R. Leigh Frackelton(x1452)
Society of Physics Students OrgSync The Society of Physics Students aims to teach, remind, and explore physics through on and off campus lectures, experiments, and workshops. There are activities for majors and non-majors alike. Student Contact: Lauren Nelson Faculty Advisor: George King(x1432)
Sociology and Anthropology Society OrgSync The Sociology and Anthropology Society (also called Culture Club) provides a social forum for students interested in these disciplines to meet and explore related issues. Student Contact: Patricia McCloy Laura Dick Faculty Advisor: Eric Gable
UMW Club Softball OrgSync The UMW Club Softball team is an all female undergrad student club that provides the opportunity for full-time students to play competitive softball against other club school teams. It welcomes students at all skill levels. Student Contact: Candice Hicks Faculty Advisor: Theresa Kennedy
UMW Street Hockey Club OrgSync Pick up street hockey. No skating required. We welcome anyone with any level of experience. Student Contact: Conan Smeeth Faculty Advisor: Neil Tilbert(x1423)
Student Anti-Violent Educators (SAVE) OrgSync SAVE works to educate the student body about relationships and signs of healthy and unhealthy relationships. We host the Red Flag Campaign and the White Ribbon Campaign. Student Contact: Meagan Holbrook  Faculty Advisor: Ray Tuttle
Student Art Association To promote and support student art on campus and in the Fr3edericksburg community Student Contact: Mattson Fields  Emily Nicolaides Faculty Advisor: J. McMillan
Student Education Association (SEA) OrgSync The SEA is a local chapter of the student Virginia Education Association, a pre-professional organization for future teachers, affiliated with the Virginia Education Association. Student Contact: Valerie Drogo Advisor:  Dale Wright(x1351)
Students Educating and Empowering for Diversity (SEED) OrgSync To raise awareness on campus about diversity and other cultures through workshops and residential facilitation. Student Contact: Marjahn Goodman Advisor:  Donald Rallis(x1492)
Students For Life Students for Life’s primary goal is to provide an educational forum for students and faculty regarding the issue of abortion and to provide opportunities for activism in the pro-life movement. Student Contact:  Julia Wood Faculty Advisor: Elizabeth Larus(x1497)
Student Government Association (SGA) OrgSync The SGA is a forum where students bring their concerns about campus issues ranging from academics to safety. We are the students’ link with the administration. Student Contact: Jeremy Thompson Faculty Advisor:  Cedric Rucker
Students Helping Honduras (SHH) SHH has grown to encompass thousands of committed students from chapters at college campuses across the country. Under a growing body of leadership, SHH has brought hundreds of student volunteers to Honduras since its inception. SHH will continue to work with the poorest communities in Honduras to show that students CAN make a difference. Student Contact: Patrick Emsley Faculty Advisor: W. Shawn Humphrey(x1487)
Student Hip Hop Organization SHHO strives to promote higher learning through hip-hop. The organization has selectively worked with the best up-and-coming artists, hip hop legends, like minded companies, and passionate student talents – all who have established SHHO as an organic uncompromising brand. Student Contact: Malik Thomas  Faculty Advisor: Marion Sanford(x1044)
Students with Disabilities And Their Allies (SDATA) OrgSync SDATA is a club at UMW open to all students and faculty with or without a disability. The mission of the club is to promote fair treatment, tolerance, and acceptance of disabled students by engaging the community in disability-related issues through awareness and learning. Student Contact: Nicole Dobson Faculty Advisor: Chris Foss (x1128)
Swim Club OrgSync Swim Club is for new and old swimmers to exercise and compete together, as well as bond outside of the pool. Student Contact: Charlotte Johnson Faculty Advisor: Mark Mermelstein
Swing Dance Club OrgSync The Swing Dance Club’s purpose is to bring swing dancing to the UMW campus and teach anyone who wants to learn. Student Contact: Kathleen Nelson Faculty Advisor: Mary Rigsby(x1540)
Symfonics OrgSync Symfonics is UMW’s oldest co-ed A Cappella group. We arrange and sing a variety of music and are always excited to perform in, and out, of the Mary Washington community! Student Contact: Melissa Getz Faculty Advisor: Jason James
Talk to the Hands Club OrgSync Talk to the Hands is a club for UMW students, faculty and alumni interested in American Sign Language and deaf culture. Student Contact: Rachel Icard Faculty Advisor: Dan Hubbard(x1460)
Tennis Club OrgSync UMW Club Tennis strives to maintain and enhance tennis skills in a fun, competitive, team-building environment at college. We play many schools in the state of Virginia and Maryland throughout the year. We have also gotten to the National Championships for the past two years. Student Contact: Chris Rieve  Faculty Advisor:  Don Paitrick(x2483)
Terrapins Synchronized Swimming Team OrgSync The purpose of the Terrapins is to compete in synchronized swimming, as well as bringing the sport into the awareness of the greater public. Student Contact: Jennifer Sustar Faculty Advisor: Mara Scanlon(x1544)
Two Dollar Challenge OrgSync The Two Dollar Challenge is dedicated to involving students in awareness and action against poverty, including through challenge week, a fundraising and awareness-raising tool. Student Contact: Emily Sherman Faculty Advisor: Shawn Humphrey(x1487)
Ultimate Frisbee (Men’s) OrgSync Men’s Ultimate competes with other schools in the sport of Ultimate Frisbee. Student Contact: Dylan Lederle-Ensign Faculty Advisor: Hai Nguyen
Ultimate Frisbee (Women) OrgSync Women’s Ultimate’s main goal is to be competitive within USAU’s Division III pool of competition. We strive to achieve this by practicing our technical skills, promoting spirit of the game, and building team cohesion. Student Contact: Devon Davis  Faculty Advisor: Stephen Davies
UNICEF UNICEF USA is an international organization dedicated to the “believe in zero.” 21,000 children die each day from preventable deaths, and the UNICEF mission is to make that number zero. The purpose of this club is to fundraiser for the children, educate the community, and advocate for children of other countries. Student Contact: Eniya Lufumpa Faculty Advisor: Ranjit Singh
The Undeniably Adjacent The Undeniably Adjacent performs free, bi-monthly improv shows for the students and faculty of University of Mary Washington. Student Contact: Mattson Fields Faculty Advisor: Steve Hampton
University Programming Council (UPC) OrgSync UPC programs all the events in the Underground, from weekly events to large scale event that take over Lee Hall. Student Contact: Amanda Buckner Faculty Advisor: Joe Mollo(x1061)
Unitarian Universalists OrgSync UMW Unitarian Universalists promote tolerance, diversity, and education by providing safe and open-minded religious discussion and fellowship on campus, for both students familiar with Unitarian Universalism and people of other faiths. Student Contact: Katie Casey Faculty Advisor: Debra Schleef(x1505)
Vegetarian Society A club for vegetarians, vegans, and anyone interested in helping animals. Our goals include maintaining a strong vegetarian presence on campus, raising money for animal rights groups, and encouraging discussion about animal rights issues. Student Contact: Kat O’Dea Faculty Advisor: Paul Messplay
Video Game Club OrgSync  The club holds weekly meetings where members bring in their own video games and equipment for other members and themselves to play with. We also hold discussions about video games, embrace video game culture, and do video game-related events as well. Our meeting place is Monroe 211 every Saturday, 8p.m. to 11p.m. Student Contact: Daniel Lipscomb Faculty Advisor: Zach Whalen(x2355)
Virginia Organizing Virginia Organizing is a statewide grassroots organization dedicated to challenging injustice by empowering people in local communities to address issues that affect the quality of their life. VA Organizing emphasizes the participation of those who have traditionally had little or no voice in our society. Student Contact: Dawn Googe Faculty Advisor: Kristin Marsh(x1501)
Voices for Planned Parenthood (VOX) VOX works in conjunction with Planned Parenthood to provide safe sex education and easy contraception as well as giving students a chance to lobby for reproductive rights. Student Contact: Claire Pickard Faculty Advisor: Connie Smith
Voices of Praise The purpose of this organization is to promote and cultivate spiritual growth, as well as the promotion of cultural and educational awareness of spiritual music at the University of Mary Washington and in its community. Student Contact: Tyshawnda Silver Faculty Advisor: Lori Johnson
Volleyball (Women) OrgSync To create a competitive, fun and team-oriented environment for girls interested in competitive volleyball. Student Contact: Kylie Kerr Faculty Advisor: John Broome
Volleyball (Co-Ed) OrgSync We are a traveling club sport that gives both men and women the opportunity to play competitive volleyball and have fun. Student Contact: Robin Kresge Faculty Advisor: Claudia Emerson
WMWC Radio Station  OrgSync The purpose of the WMWC Radio Station is to train interested Mary Washington community members to provide audio broadcasting entertainment for the Mary Washington community and other interested listeners. Student Contact: Mike Powers Faculty Advisor:  Ray Tuttle(x1660)
Women of Color (WOC) OrgSync This club is designed to educate, celebrate, and empower males and females of different races and cultures. Student Contact: Jessica Robinson Jasmine Cook Faculty Advisor: Greta Franklin(x2179)
Wrestling Club OrgSync Wrestling Club is a sports club dedicated to wrestling. Student Contact: Jared Smith Faculty Advisor Mark Mermelstein
Yarn Works OrgSync Yarn Works is a club devoted to the encouragement of knitting and crocheting, as well as to develop new friendships. Student Contact: Amanda Vercruysse  Faculty Advisor:  Deborah O’Dell(x1417)
Young Democrats OrgSync UMW Young Democrats is a group of politically active students dedicated to the goals and principles of the Democratic Party by promoting the interest and understanding of young people in government and the political process. Assisting in elections, political trips, registering students to vote and community service are among our club’s activities. Student Contact: Ally Blanck Faculty Advisor: Ben LaBreche
Young Life Young Life is a mission community of Christ-centered adults committed to sharing the message of Jesus Christ with adolescents in the Greater Fredericksburg community. Young Life provides biblical teaching and training toward students who want to become volunteer leaders. Student Contact: Ellen Smethurst  Faculty Advisor: H. Nicole Frye Myers (x8026)
Young Women’s Leadership Program Club (YWLP) YWLP provides college students with one-on-one and group mentoring for 7th grade girls in the Fredericksburg Area. Student Contact: Heather Curry Faculty Advisor: Dawn Bowen(x1491)

item.title: Open Positions
item.dc:creator: dsnel0lx
item.content:encoded:
The Administrative Review Process

The University of Mary Washington has recently hired a third-party consultant to look at our universities academic and non-academic programs. In addition to things like administrative expenses, non-academic programs consist of programs like student activities that are pivotal to student life. The two students selected by the Student Government Association Executive Cabinet will serve as full committee members and will provide feedback on behalf of student body. This process will continue from February until the fall of 2013. The deadline for applications is Sunday, February 3, 2013. After reviewing all applications, the SGA Executive Cabinet will contact selected applicants for interviews. At the conclusion of the process, Executive Cabinet will select two students whom they feel will serve the student body well and accurately convey student concerns to the committee. The work required for student committee members will include attending one, two-hour meeting every other week and being responsible for a significant amount of reading and preparation. The students selected to serve on the committee must be able to participate for the next two semesters and can gain academic credit for their service. (The form of academic credit remains to be determined.) If you have any questions, please contact the Student Government Association at sga@mail.umw.edu.

At this time, the SGA is no longer accepting applications.

To find out more about SGA positions please visit Elections.

item.title: College Leadership Program
item.dc:creator: dsnel0lx
item.content:encoded:
Leadership Program Gives UMW Students a Taste of Political World

June 18, 2012 By Brynn Boyer
At the Sorensen Institute of Political Leadership’s College Leaders Program, party lines are set aside. Participants are not allowed to disclose their political affiliations to each other. Sean Simons, Meghan Hobbs and Brendan Oudekerk are among 18 college students and recent graduates chosen for the Sorensen Institute's College Leaders Program “It bonds everybody together,” Brendan Oudekerk said. “It is really refreshing to get along with everybody…and know we are working toward common goals. Each person brings different qualities to the table.” Oudekerk, a 2012 graduate of the University of Mary Washington, and UMW seniors Meghan Hobbs and Sean Simons are among 18 college students or recent graduates who were selected for the four-week-long summer program held at the University of Virginia. The College Leaders Program, now in its eighth year, brings together youth leaders from across Virginia with a focus on ethics, bipartisanship, public policy and civic engagement. The Sorensen Institute was founded as the Virginia Institute of Political Leadership in 1993 in hopes it would identify and bring together Virginia’s emerging political leaders. More than 1,200 Virginian students have graduated from the Institute. For Oudekerk, who is working toward a career in economic development, the program is a chance to network and learn more about Virginia politics. “As a graduate, I’m using it to be more well-rounded,” he said. “It helps to come together with people from different backgrounds.” The 18 program participants are divided into three groups – economics, higher education or transportation – to develop policy proposals. The groups will present their findings at the end of the program, in hopes a Virginia legislator will want to adopt the proposal. One of last year’s groups actually got a bill passed, Hobbs explained. “That’s everyone’s aspiration,” she said. Hobbs, an international affairs and political science major, plans to attend law school after graduation, but also is interested in politics. “I have been wanting to get a look into state politics,” she said, “so this program is really helping me with that.” On Tuesday, June 12, the students met with Sen. Mark Warner and Sen. Jim Webb at the U.S. Capitol Building. Simons, chair of UMW’s Legislative Action Committee and an intern in President Richard V. Hurley’s office, got to introduce the senators to the group: “It was an honor to have that privilege,” he said. When the program ends on June 23, Simons says the experience of a respectful, bipartisan atmosphere will stick with him. “A lot of issues are played in the media as being very polarizing, but people, especially my age, are much more willing to compromise and come together to find solutions,” he said. “I have a greater appreciation for what I think our generation can do.”

item.title: Legislative
item.dc:creator: dsnel0lx
item.content:encoded:
Student Senate

Student Senate is the Legislative Branch of the Student Government Association. The Senate can legislate on any issue concerning students. All motions go through one of ten Senate Committees: Academic and Faculty Affairs, Buildings and Grounds, Constitutional Order, Dining Advisory, Election Rules and Procedures, Ethics and Conduct, Legislative and Administrative Affairs, Publicity, Telecommunications, and Environmental Sustainability before it’s voted on the floor.

Senators are chosen through elections at the beginning of each academic year through the residence halls and the student body at-large.

The SGA Vice-President serves as President of Senate and its official spokesperson. The Vice-President of Senate is elected at the beginning of each academic year from among the current senators. The Parliamentarian and Secretary are appointed by the President of Senate.

You are still able to join the Senate during the school year by collecting fifty signatures from people at the University of Mary Washington. After you’ve gained enough signatures, show up to a senate meeting and request to be admitted into the ranks of the Senate. It’s always a good idea to email the Senate President ahead of time to do this.

President of Senate: Robert Belcourt

Vice-President: Monique dela Cruz

Parliamentarian: Stephanie Preston

Secretary: Laila Ayub

To learn more about Student Senate contact the the current President of Senate, Robert Belcourt at rbelcour@mail.umw.edu.

To submit a motion for consideration feel free to download the motion sheet here or fill out this online form. It’s your school, your voice, your SGA.

item.dc:creator: dsnel0lx
item.content:encoded:
The Executive Cabinet

Executive Cabinet
President: Stephanie Preston
Vice President: Nate Levine
Honor Council President: Alice O’Brien
Legislative Action Committee Chairperson: Joe Dolan
Association of Residence Halls President: Alyssa Lieurance
Commuter Student Association President: Claire Pickard
Academic Affairs Committee Chairperson: Lavar Edmonds
Diversity and Unity Coordinating Committee Chair: Christian Wiedow
Inter-Club Association President: Rob Jarvis
Judicial Review Board President: Andrew Gabany
Executive Coordinator: Samantha Worman
Communications Director: Chelsea Kopf
Director of Community Outreach: Rad Wan Jarrar
Technology Coordinator: Gibran Parvez
Treasurer: Sarah Clay
Secretary: Amanda Motley



The Executive Cabinet represents the student body on all matters that are of concern between the administration and of the student body. The Executive Cabinet is the highest elected body on campus. The members of the Executive Cabinet include voting members and non-voting members. The voting members are: the President, the Vice-President, the Judicial Review Board President, the Honor Council President, the Legislative Action Committee Chairperson, the Academic Affairs Council Chairperson, the Association of Residence Halls President, the Commuting Student Association President, the Diversity and Unity Coordinating Committee Executive Chairperson, the Inter-Club Association President. The Constitutional non-voting members are: the Executive Coordinator, the Director of Community Outreach, the Treasurer, the Secretary, and the Technology Coordinator. Each member of the Executive Cabinet has a full voice at all meetings. Executive Cabinet meetings are open to anyone who would like to participate.

item.title: Judicial
item.dc:creator: dsnel0lx
item.content:encoded:
The Judicial System

It’s all about living and learning together. . .  Students at the University of Mary Washington are entitled to a community that is conducive to their safety, personal growth, and academic success. By providing expectations for responsible conduct, and by having a judicial system that responds when community standards may have been violated, the University seeks to maintain a balance between the rights of individual community members and the rights of the community as a whole. The judicial system includes the Director of Judicial Affairs and Community Responsibility, professional members of the Residence Life staff, the Student Conduct Hearing Board, and the Judicial Review Board (JRB). (The Honor Council is a separate entity, and is not part of the judicial system.) PHILOSOPHY: Judicial Affairs and Community Responsibility The University’s judicial system seeks to balance the needs of individual students and the needs of the surrounding community. Education is the system’s primary goal — specifically, assisting students to develop a sense of ethics and responsibility to themselves, to each other, and to the communities in which they study, work, and live. Furthermore, when students behave in a manner that is inconsistent with the standards of the University, it also is a goal of the judicial system to educate them about the consequences of their conduct, and to provide them with the tools to make decisions that are consistent with both responsibility to themselves and responsibility to their community. The President of the University is charged with responsibility for all aspects of student life at the University. Therefore, the administration must ensure that the campus environment remains safe, comfortable, and supportive of the mission and standards of the institution. The “Statement of Community Values” provides a template for those standards. Some behaviors cannot be tolerated because they threaten the basic safety and well-being of others in the University community. Other behaviors, while less serious, have an adverse impact on the University’s educational mission. Rules and regulations have been carefully developed to minimize the risk of harm to all members of the University community, and to maximize the ability of students to achieve excellence in all areas. In addition, local, state and federal laws have been considered in developing the University’s rules, regulations, and judicial policies. The Code of Conduct lists expectations UMW has of all its students. However, an academic community should provide many opportunities for self-government. To this end, authority has been delegated to students through organizations such as the Student Government Association, the Student Senate, and the Judicial Review Board, and through Self-determination by Community Standards. The University’s judicial system and the Code of Conduct are administered by the Office of Judicial Affairs and Community Responsibility. The Office maintains oversight over administrative hearings, the Judicial Review Board, and the Student Conduct Hearing Board. Because student behavior, character development, and ethics go hand in hand, the Office of Judicial Affairs and Community Responsibility supports programming that raises students’ awareness of ethical issues – from individual to global – that are present in contemporary society. It also assists students to resolve conflicts that may arise by using alternatives to the judicial process, including mediation. SELF-DETERMINATION BY COMMUNITY STANDARDS The University’s dedication to a liberal arts education is reflected in its policy of self-determination. Each residence hall* is viewed as a living-learning center whose goal is to enrich each student’s educational experience. Under the policy of self-determination, the residents of each hall, with the guidance of Residence Life staff members, develop guidelines and procedures of governance for living which allow for both individual freedom and respect for the privacy and personal rights of others in the community. Residents in each hall exercise this responsibility of self-governance through Hall Councils. Students develop guidelines called community standards which pertain to the maintenance of a clean and orderly environment, the establishment of quiet and courtesy hours, the regulation of visitation of guests, the assurance of a reasonable level of safety and security, and the regulation of conduct which infringes on the rights of other residents. The policies and procedures, adopted by Hall Councils as the community standards for each hall, must be compatible with University policy, public laws, and the academic objectives of a residential, educational community. The individual’s right to privacy and freedom of personal choice, and the educational goals of the University must always be ensured. Each student has the right to counsel with a member of the Residence Life staff concerning problems arising from self-determination. The staff of Residence Life and the Office of Judicial Affairs and Community Responsibility have the right to intervene to ensure that the rights of all students are respected. The ultimate goal is to build communities in which individuals are not harassed, excluded, or made to feel uncomfortable because of sex, color, religion, sexual orientation, disability, lifestyle, or political beliefs. The University years should allow the exploration and development of personal identity and values, and this exploration can best take place in an atmosphere of mutual respect, understanding, and self-determination. *NOTE: The words “residence hall” or “hall” are used interchangeably and refer to any residential unit associated with campus. No differentiation is made between residence halls and houses in the policies and guidelines set forth in this section. Self-Determination by Community Standards in the residence halls Students and staff are prepared for participation in this program by receiving training to enhance their interpersonal skills. Students will find these skills useful when deciding Community Standards (rules governing various aspects of residence hall life). Resident Assistants will meet with small groups of students, who will discuss and decide (by consensus) the rights and responsibilities of community members. Rules such as quiet hours, visitation, damages, smoke-free areas, 24-hour study rooms, and kitchen use are negotiables which the students may decide upon. Students may choose to adhere to the rules which have already been set as a standard in the Student Handbook. These rules will remain in place until the residents reach a different decision. Safety regulations and policies based upon the Code of Virginia and/or federal laws are not negotiable. Issues which may affect the entire building, such as quiet hours and visitation, will be decided by the community based upon recommendations from individual hall groups. If a rule does not seem to be appropriate or working, any member of the community may present a proposal to Hall Council for reconsideration during a scheduled meeting. Once the rules of the residence hall have been decided, these rules should be posted. Alleged violations of individual or community rights may be reported and/or documented by any member of the community. Incident reports are completed and routed to the appropriate disciplinary process as outlined elsewhere in this section. The Self-determination by Community Standards concept reflects a strong preference for educational rather than punitive outcomes in instances where University policies are violated. Where these approaches are not successful or not appropriate, the judicial processes are designed to enforce adherence to the rules on community standards and protect the interests of individuals who are being victimized as well as the community at large. Each disciplinary situation is handled on a case-by-case basis. Given the individual nature of each situation, there is no set list of mandatory sanctions attached to specific violations. Hall Councils The Hall Council serves as the representative governing body for each residence hall. The Hall Council is comprised of the president, vice president, treasurer, secretary, and historian; the social/publicity and recycling chairpersons; and floor representatives. Building supervisors serve as Hall Council advisors and act as a valuable resource for facilitating community development. Councils serve to coordinate the community standards program within each residence hall and also strive to build community and promote a positive, healthy atmosphere in each hall. The role of Self-Determination by Community Standards (fall semester) During the first few weeks of the fall semester, Resident Assistants will convene and conduct floor meetings to discuss and decide upon the rules and regulations that will serve as community standards for the floor. Rules that affect other floors or the entire building must be presented to the building residents for a vote. The voting process is as follows: 1) at least 66% of building residents must vote; then, 2) a majority of the vote will determine the outcome. The role of Self-Determination by Community Standards (spring semester) During the first few weeks of spring semester, fall semester community standards are to be reviewed by the Hall Council of each building. Changes are to be discussed and voted upon. All changes are to be announced throughout the residence hall. After initial spring semester revisions are made, the Hall Council proposal format should be used to recommend changes in policies, procedures, services, or community standards. Self-Determination by Community Standards outside the residence halls Commuting students also benefit from the concept of self-determination. Furthermore, not all community standards concerning students who live in the residence halls apply to residence hall settings. Under the auspices of the Student Government Association (SGA), the Student Senate has the responsibility to legislate with regard to all issues of student concern.

item.title: Home
item.dc:creator: mdunlap
item.content:encoded:
The Student Government Association is here to remind you that your voice matters. 

The SGA is your voice to the administration. We’re here to remind you that your voice matters more than ever. We are a forum where students bring their concerns about campus issues ranging from academics to safety. We address local, state, and national issues which affect students while organizing community events to foster school spirit, and work together to bond the community. SGA Executive Cabinet and Senate Meeting Minutes are updated regularly, please check back for new information. We are so committed to representing you that we even have a representative at every level of the administration… including the Board of Visitors.

item.title: Elections
item.dc:creator: mdunlap
item.content:encoded:
It’s the question we’re all asking. Will you lead?

Every year, students have the opportunity to participate in a process that is amazing. Students have a chance to serve as members of the Executive Cabinet of the Student Government Association. As the highest elected body on campus, the Student Government Association has the duty of articulating the student voice to the administration and beyond. The cabinet of 17 people represent the entire student body at UMW and then –under the direction of the SGA President– work to find solutions for common problems on campus. The SGA strives to work together to turn UMW Problems into solutions. Each member of the cabinet has a different job that they do that benefits the student body in a different way. The question you have to ask yourself is… will you lead?

How do you run to serve UMW?

To run for office you must attend an election workshop or contact the SGA by March 11th, 2013 by midnight (sga@mail.umw.edu) to become nominated. Election workshops are Monday March 11, 2013 and Tuesday March 12, 2013 at 5PM in the Underground. Nominations will be Wednesday March 13, 2013 in the James Farmer Lecture Hall (Monroe 116) at 4:30 PM. The results of the Executive Cabinet Elections will be announced Wednesday March 20, 2013. For more questions, please contact the SGA.

 The Office of the President

The President of the SGA is the official voice of the SGA and the Student Body. The president is responsible for the efficient operation of the SGA and reports to President Hurley. The SGA President also presents a report to the Board of Visitors and advocated for all of the students needs. and preferences. The Student Body President is responsible for the efficient operation of the SGA. The President appoints all students to committees on campus. The SGA President has the power to fill appointed positions which are as follows: The Executive Coordinator, the Communications Director, the Director of Community Outreach, the Technology Coordinator, the Treasurer and the Secretary. To become SGA President, a student must be enrolled at the University of Mary Washington at the time of nominations, be in good academic standing (2.2 or above) and no pending judicial charges.

The Office of the Vice President

The Vice President is the official voice of the Senate and takes over if the President is unable to fulfill their duties. The Vice President is in charge of the daily operation of the Senate and will appoint all the committee chairpersons at the start of each new academic year. The Vice President bring the Executive Cabinet all senate motions for their consideration. To become SGA Vice President, a student must be enrolled at the University of Mary Washington at the time of nominations, be in good academic standing (2.2 or above) and no pending judicial charges. Furthermore, you must have served one semester in the Senate, including the semester in which you are running for election.

The Honor Council President

The Honor Council President represents the SGA on all issues of Honor while leading the Honor Council during hearings. The Honor Council President leads the judicial branch of the SGA ensuring every student is aware of Honor and how it impact their lives at UMW. To become Honor Council President, a student must be enrolled at the University of Mary Washington at the time of nominations, be in good academic standing (2.2 or above) and no pending judicial charges. 

The Office Legislative Action Committee Chairperson

The LAC Chair is responsible for dealing with all politics that affect the university. The LAC Chair works with the local, state and federal government on all issues that benefit or affect Mary Washington. The LAC Chair works with the SGA to plan Lobby Day, Constitution Day and works to advice the SGA on all issues that are political in nature.

The Office of the Commuting Student Association President

The CSA President is responsible for representing commuter students to SGA, all University Offices and the Fredericksburg Community. The CSA President will work to improve life for commuter students at Mary Washington though student life and other activities. To be the CSA President, the Student must be a commuter.

The Association of Residence Halls President

The ARH President represents all issues of residence life to the SGA. They’ve helped work on projects like Party Smart this year and help students work with Hall Councils to achieve various goals in their Residence Halls.

The Academic Affairs Committee Chairperson

The AAC Chair works to represent students to our amazing faculty. The Chair works with the faculty often to articulate what students are thinking and then in turn return those concerns back to the SGA. In the upcoming year, the AAC Chair will work to ensure student voices are heard in the University Faculty Governance Structure.

The Office of the Diversity and Unity Coordinating Committee Executive Chairperson

The DUCC Executive Chairperson is responsible for running all DUCC meetings and works to correspond with the administration and faculty in regards to programming of DUCC initiatives. The DUCC Executive Chairperson will appoint their own Vice President within two weeks of being elected.

The Office of the Inter-Club Association President

The ICA President organizes the Club Presidents meeting each month for the purpose of distributing information that concern the students involved. The ICA President works with the Executive Cabinet to admit new clubs into ICA.

Judicial Review Board President

The JRB is also a branch of the Judicial side of the SGA and is responsible for fair hearings for students who violate the code of conduct.
